content: many tabletop crafters have asked if there's a cheaper alternative to the
procs on hotwire table well of course there is and today I'd like to compare
one of them in a head-to-head cutting showdown so you can decide for yourself
if those savings are worth it or not hey guys welcome back to another episode of
black magic craft this week is an episode that I've been planning on doing
for a long time I want to take the procs on hot wire table and the hot wire foam
factory scroll table put them side by side and do the same cuts on them so
that you guys can see how they perform in comparison a lot of people ask about
the cheaper alternatives to the procs on because it is a fairly expensive tool if
this is just a casual hobby so obviously people are looking for cheaper solutions
and one of those cheaper solutions that comes up all the time is the hot wire
foam factory scroll table there's no question that I am a user and lover and
advocate of the procs on table but I do own both I am in a unique position where
I can compare the two and let you guys decide for yourself in this comparison
I'm only going to perform a few basic cuts because I think that's the best way
to just show the efficiency with which each one of these tools operates there
is no beating around the bush the procs on table itself has a lot more options
and control and you can do more with it and I'm going to talk about that after
the comparison but first let's take a look at how quickly these tools cut foam
side-by-side and how quick it is to set up the procedure to do these cuts let's
take a look
there you have it a side-by-side comparison and you can
come to your own conclusions from that I gotta say though when I was planning to
do this video I actually thought the hot wire foam factory scroll table would
perform a lot worse than it did it's kind of strange I haven't used the tool
in quite some time it was the first hot wire cutter that I purchased and when I
first used it I was a little bit frustrated with how well it cut the foam
it didn't quite do what I expected and then I purchased the procs on and I
loved it and I've been using it ever since
and in my head I've had this kind of maybe a little bit unfair false memory
about how poorly the hot wire foam factory scroll table performed I'm still
not gonna say it's great personally I think that you know it's not worth the
money to save because it is gonna be frustrating to use it's very slow and it
can't do a lot of the same things the procs on Kent but I got to give it
credit it did perform a bit better than I remembered now there's a few things to
consider besides just the speed of cutting and efficiency of tool use when
comparing these two tools and deciding which one is right for you obviously
there's the price the hot wire foam factory one is considerably cheaper so
if that's the only thing you care about well it's a winner in that regard but
there's a lot of other stuff one is the features now the one feature that the
proc son has that makes it far superior in my eyes to the hot wire foam factory
one is the temperature adjustment you can regulate the temperature from very
cool to very hot to adjust depending on the material you're using the thickness
of it and the width of the cut or the type of cut it's that is very important
when working with one of these tools that being said I don't think this is an
apples-to-apples comparison and I think it's a little bit of an unfair
comparison to our foam factory the scroll table is their entry level I
would say hobbyist tool it's not fully featured they do have a scroll table
that is more expensive and of a higher quality and that one is actually more
than the procs on so there's no good way to compare the tools because the proxxon
price point is in between the two other ones now the hot wire foam factory other
scroll table you can buy uses a separate power supply where I believe you can
adjust the temperature so it exists it's just not a feature on the cheaper one if
you're looking for a cheaper alternative so that's what we're talking about here
is the cheaper alternative another thing that's vastly different about the two is
the wire the gauge of wire used on the hot wire foam factory cutter is
significantly thicker which means it doesn't get quite as hot and it doesn't
make as clean of a cut sometimes I far prefer the very thin proxxon wire that
being said the procs on wire breaks way more often I've actually never broken
the hot wire foam factory wire but the procs on comes with like a spool of a
hundred feet of wire so I don't think it's really an issue I don't know if
I'll ever go through it all in a year I've probably used three feet of wire
from breaks that's another point if you're gonna order one of these on
Amazon don't bother ordering the extra spool of
wire I really doubt you're gonna need it just
buy the whole tool comes with more than enough wire the other thing to consider
out of the box is the RIP fence neither of them come with a really great
rip fence the procs on one is kind of famously flexible and loose so it's not
perfect but it works it also doubles as a cross cut guide and it's very quick to
adjust and set up the hot wire foam factory rip fence is a little piece of
plastic with two set screws that's very finicky and annoying to set I do not
like it whatsoever it also creates a funny thing the procs
on you're able to adjust this wire at an angle and rip bevels
now the funny thing is on the hot wire foam factory one you can also adjust the
arm to angle the wire except that the direction which the RIP fence runs on
the table means that it doesn't matter what angle
your wires at if you're ripping it's still going to be a straight cut because
you have to cut towards the fence to get that bevel and it
maybe I'm missing something but straight-up just doesn't make sense to
me another feature that the proc son has that the hot wire foam factory one does
not isn't on/off switch and that might not seem like a big deal but when you're
cutting a lot of foam it is important because as discussed in previous videos
it is safe to cut this foam with the hot wire but it's dangerous to burn it and
when foam residue collects on the wire it will start to burn so it's good
practice to turn your tool off when you've done with the cut proxxon
actually makes a foot pedal that you can get which I should get I would love to
have that and that makes that feature even better
another huge factor to consider is the fact that the proximal table is kind of
the hobby standard in terms of terrain building which means that there's a lot
of people using it and a lot of people developing accessories for it
shifting Lance comm makes many many props on accessories that are fantastic
they are so well designed and well used and they take a good tool and turn it
into a fantastic tool as far as I know that same kind of aftermarket accessory
business doesn't exist for the hot wire boom factory when I'm not even sure how
it would work because it doesn't have a way to kind of lock stuff in having said
in the demo I did use this on the scroll table just held it in place so that I
could at least get a fair you know vertical cut comparison so that is a
bunch of information about both I'm reluctant to say what you should do but
personally it's a clear winner on the proxxon I think that the extra cost is a
hundred percent worth it in my eyes the cost of the hot wire foam factory one
although cheaper is kind of a waste of money I personally really regret having
purchased it and I wish I hadn't done that or
early on when I got into this hobby I wish I just right out the gate had
bought the Brock's on sorry guys that's that is that is the honest truth I would
say that if the procs on table is out of your price range and it is not an option
whatsoever despite all of these things my advice to you is don't spend some
money on a cheaper hotwire table I think honestly if you're not gonna go out and
get the proxxon you're better off investing in just an Olfa knife with a
big pack of blades some good straight edges and work that way or make your own
this is where the real answer is for a cheaper alternative to the procs on for
the price of the hot wire foam factory one or probably even less you can build
yourself a beautiful fully functioning high-power good-quality
hot wire cutter obviously there is a learning curve and and and stuff
involved in that but if you're capable builder and you feel comfortable doing
some basic electronics and woodworking you can make a hot wire cutter that is
just as good as the proxxon maybe even better because you can customize it for
very cheap so when somebody asks is there a cheaper alternative that's worth
getting to the procs on the answer is yes but it's I don't think it's the hot
wire foam factory one I don't think it's those cheap $20 Hobby Lobby ones that I
don't even want to waste the money on to test I think the cheap alternative is
building your own we're just not using one using a knife I am NOT gonna make a
video on making a cutter because there are many other ones online you just
search how to build a hot wire cutter king of random made a fantastic one but
there's many people who have made them there's a lot of resources online you
can definitely make your home that being said I don't think you
should buy the procs on because it's just I really I really love it it's
changed my crafting game and I'm so bad I purchased it so with that being said
you got your holiday Amazon gift cards or whatever and you're itching to spend
them take my advice with a grain of salt I am but a lowly crafter using the tools
and telling you what I think if you want to purchase a procs on or even the hot
wire for macaroon I mean I'm not going to judge if you want to purchase any

essential equipment store that'll take you through a link that is my Amazon

really don't if you found this video useful hit that like button drop me a
